contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} In [[Irish folklore|Irish]] and [[Scottish folklore]], the '''Sluagh''' ({{IPA-ga|sɫuə}}, {{IPA-gd|slˠ̪uaɣ|lang}}) were the spirits of the restless dead. Sometimes they were seen as sinners, or generally evil people who were welcome in neither heaven nor hell, nor in the [[Other World|Otherworld]], who had also been rejected by the [[Celtic Polytheism|Celtic]] deities and by the earth itself. Whichever the underlying belief, they are almost always depicted as troublesome and destructive. They were seen to fly in groups like flocks of birds, coming from the west, and were known to try to enter the house of a dying person in an effort to carry the soul away with them. West-facing windows were sometimes kept closed to keep them out. Some consider the Sluagh to also carry with them the souls of innocent people who were kidnapped by these destructive spirits. Lewis Spence writes in 'The Magic Arts in Celtic Britain':<ref>Spence, Lewis (1945) The Magic Arts in Celtic Britain p. 88 ISBN 0-09-474300-2</ref> ''In the Western Isles of Scotland the Sluagh, or fairy host, was regarded as composed of the souls of the dead flying through the air, and the feast of the dead at Hallowe'en was likewise the festival of the fairies.'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[Fairy]] *[[Classifications of fairies]] {{Fairies}} [[Category:Irish legendary creatures]] [[Category:Irish words and phrases]] [[Category:Scottish mythology]] [[Category:Scottish folklore]] [[Category:Undead]] [[Category:Monsters]]
